review.title: A Universal Part-of-Speech Tagset
review.abstract: To facilitate future research in unsupervised induction of syntactic structure and to standardize best-practices, we propose a tagset that consists of twelve universal part-of-speech categories. In addition to the tagset, we develop a mapping from 25 different treebank tagsets to this universal set. As a result, when combined with the original treebank data, this universal tagset and mapping produce a dataset consisting of common parts-of-speech for 22 different languages. We highlight the use of this resource via two experiments, including one that reports competitive accuracies for unsupervised grammar induction without gold standard part-of-speech tags.

sections.heading: 3 Experiments
sections.text: To demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed universal POS tagset, we conducted two experiments: First, we trained the same supervised POS tagging model for language comparison on all of the above tree trunks and evaluated the accuracy of marking on the universal POS tagset. Second, we used universal POS tags (automatically projected from English) as a starting point for unattended grammar induction and produced completely unattended parsers for multiple languages.

sections.heading: 3.1 Language Comparisons
sections.text: To compare the accuracy of POS marking in different languages, we trained a supervised marker based on a Trigram-Markov model (Brants, 2000) on all tree banks. We chose this model for its fast speed and (almost) state-of-the-art accuracy without language-specific tuning.2Table 1 shows the results for all 25 tree banks during training / testing on the original (O) and universal (U) marker sets. Overall, the deviation from the universal marker set was reduced by half (5.1 instead of 10.4). But of course, there are still differences in accuracy between the different languages. On the one hand, the Japanese marker remains almost deterministic in the face of golden segmentation, resulting in a final accuracy of over 99%. [3] Marking Turkish, an agglutinative language with an average sentence length of 11.6 tokens, is very challenging, resulting in an accuracy of only 90.2%.

sections.heading: 3.2 Grammar Induction
sections.text: In fact, it is a purely reactionary project that sees itself in a position to change and change the world, at a time when the world is able to change the world, to change and change the world, to change the world, to change the world, to change the world, to change, to change the world, to change, to change, to change, to change, to change, to change, to change, to change, to change, to change, to change, to change the world, to widen, to widen, to widen, to widen, to widen, to widen, to widen, to widen, to widen, to widen, to widen, to widen, to widen, to widen, to widen, to widen, to widen, to widen.

sections.heading: 4 Conclusions
sections.text: We proposed a twelve-category POS tagset that exists across all languages, and developed a mapping of 25 language-specific tagsets to this universal tagset. We demonstrated experimentally that the universal POS categories generalize far beyond language boundaries in an unattended grammar introduction task, providing competitive analytical accuracy without relying on golden POS tags. The tagset and mappings can be downloaded from http: / / code.google.com / p / universal-pos-tags /.

sections.heading: Acknowledgements
sections.text: We thank Joakim Nivre for permission to use a provisional tagset mapping used in the work of McDonald and Nivre (2007), the second author being partially supported by the NSF grant IIS-0844507.

called universals to represent their cross-lingual nature (Carnie, 2002; Newmeyer, 2005). For example, Naseem et al. (2009) used the Multext-East (Erjavec, 2004) corpus to evaluate their multi-lingual POS induction system, because it uses the same tagset for multiple languages. When corpora with common tagsets are unavailable, a standard approach is to manually define a mapping from language and treebank specific fine-grained tagsets to a predefined universal set. This was the approach taken by Das and Petrov (2011) to evaluate their cross-lingual POS projection system for six different languages.
Second, we combine the cross-lingual projection part-of-speech taggers of Das and Petrov (2011) with the grammar induction system of Naseem et al.

While there might be some disagreement about the exact definition of an universal POS tagset (Evans and Levinson, 2009), it seems fairly indisputable that a set of coarse POS categories (or syntactic universals) exists across all languages in one form or another (Carnie, 2002; Newmeyer, 2005).

While there might be some disagreement about the exact definition of an universal POS tagset (Evans and Levinson, 2009), it seems fairly indisputable that a set of coarse POS categories (or syntactic universals) exists across all languages in one form or another (Carnie, 2002; Newmeyer, 2005).

While there might be some disagreement about the exact definition of an universal POS tagset (Evans and Levinson, 2009), it seems fairly indisputable that a set of coarse POS categories (or syntactic universals) exists across all languages in one form or another (Carnie, 2002; Newmeyer, 2005).

Similarly, the organizers of the CoNLL shared tasks on dependency parsing provide coarse (but still language specific) tags in addition to the finegrained tags used in the original treebanks (Buchholz and Marsi, 2006; Nivre et al., 2007).

In fact, Smith and Eisner (2005) made a similar observation and defined a collapsed set of 17 English POS tags (instead of the original 45) that has subsequently been adopted by most unsupervised POS induction work.

Similarly, the organizers of the CoNLL shared tasks on dependency parsing provide coarse (but still language specific) tags in addition to the finegrained tags used in the original treebanks (Buchholz and Marsi, 2006; Nivre et al., 2007). McDonald and Nivre (2007) identified eight different coarse POS tags when analyzing the errors of two dependency parsers on the 13 different languages from the CoNLL shared tasks.

While all languages have a way of describing the properties of objects (which themselves are typically referred to with nouns), many have argued that Korean does not technically have adjectives, but instead expresses properties of nouns via stative verbs (Kim, 2002).

To decouple the challenges of POS tagging and parsing, golden POS tags are typically assumed in unsupervised grammar induction experiments (Carroll and Charniak, 1992; Klein and Manning, 2004).

These rules are specified using a set of universal syntactic categories, and lead to state-of-the-art grammar induction performance superior to previous methods, such as the dependency model with valence (DMV) (Klein and Manning, 2004) and the phylogenetic grammar induction model (PGI) (Berg-Kirkpatrick and Klein, 2010).

These rules are specified using a set of universal syntactic categories, and lead to state-of-the-art grammar induction performance superior to previous methods, such as the dependency model with valence (DMV) (Klein and Manning, 2004) and the phylogenetic grammar induction model (PGI) (Berg-Kirkpatrick and Klein, 2010).
To this end, we chose the framework of Naseem et al. (2010), in which a few universal syntactic rules (USR) are used to constrain a probabilistic Bayesian model.
For all languages, we used the treebanks released as a part of the CoNLL-X (Buchholz and Marsi, 2006) shared task.
In our experiments, we did not make use of refined categories, as the POS tags induced by Das and Petrov (2011) were all coarse.

In our experiments, we did not make use of refined categories, as the POS tags induced by Das and Petrov (2011) were all coarse. We present results on the same eight IndoEuropean languages as Das and Petrov (2011), so that we can make use of their automatically projected POS tags.
Not reported by Berg-Kirkpatrick and Klein (2010).

metadata.abstractText: To facilitate future research in unsupervised induction of syntactic structure and to standardize best-practices, we propose a tagset that consists of twelve universal part-ofspeech categories. In addition to the tagset, we develop a mapping from 25 different treebank tagsets to this universal set. As a result, when combined with the original treebank data, this universal tagset and mapping produce a dataset consisting of common partsof-speech for 22 different languages. We highlight the use of this resource via two experiments, including one that reports competitive accuracies for unsupervised grammar induction without gold standard part-of-speech tags.
